Also how are the barracks? do you share a room, or do you get your own room but share a common area? Also I hear things are pretty expensive down there. We'll any info would be greatly appreciated. content: Wiesbaden is a bad site to end up at. The German community around you is close to anti-american. You will be close to frankfurt which means flying in and out is easier. Small post like most of Germany except this one is so spread out you will have to have a car. Like I said there are better places to end up.
reply: Wiesbaden is a bad site to end up at. The German community around you is close to anti-american. You will be close to frankfurt which means flying in and out is easier. Small post like most of Germany except this one is so spread out you will have to have a car. Like I said there are better places to end up.
title: Being stationed in Wiesbaden, Germany

content: You will get OCONUS COLA (Cost of Living Allowance) but it isn't much at all. It depends on your Rank, # of years in, living in barracks or not and where you are stationed (I am assuming you are not going with dependents). Did a rates query for E1 to E3 with 3 years in or less, living in barrack will get $94.71 per payday for COLA. It doesn't go up to $98 until you make E4.
reply: You will get OCONUS COLA (Cost of Living Allowance) but it isn't much at all. It depends on your Rank, # of years in, living in barracks or not and where you are stationed (I am assuming you are not going with dependents). Did a rates query for E1 to E3 with 3 years in or less, living in barrack will get $94.71 per payday for COLA. It doesn't go up to $98 until you make E4.
title: Being stationed in Wiesbaden, Germany

content: Wiesbaden is awesome! Really, you have the Rhein and Mainz and all the beautiful little German towns all around you. Learn some German (I'd recommend the Pimsleur course) and get out into the towns and countryside if you can. Go volksmarching, and to weinfests and see the castles. Take the tours to England and Prague and Italy. Any place is what you make of it - if you stay in the barracks and drink all weekend (like many soldiers do) you'll hate it. I just hope you won't have to spend too much time at CMTC and Grafenwoer - if you end up in the 1st Armored Division. That's great - I envy you.
reply: Wiesbaden is awesome! Really, you have the Rhein and Mainz and all the beautiful little German towns all around you. Take the tours to England and Prague and Italy. Any place is what you make of it - if you stay in the barracks and drink all weekend (like many soldiers do) you'll hate it. I just hope you won't have to spend too much time at CMTC and Grafenwoer - if you end up in the 1st Armored Division. That's great - I envy you.

title: Being stationed in Wiesbaden, Germany

content: Having spent two years Baumholder, 55-56, and six months in Wildflecken, 57, Wiesbaden would be like Heaven. Other than the fact that B'hole and WildF'ken are cold wet miserable places 364 days a year (especially ditch digging, rock crushing M1 toting combat engineers) do you think being a slick = speedy-three had any thing to do with my not licking those places? We did love our three years in Kitzingen, 69-71. Is a lovely little town and the German citizens really like the GIs. Being a W1 - W2 and detachment commander of a data processing unit made it a little easier. God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

content: quote: Originally posted by 88miker: im stationed in mannheim. lots of old stuff around here to see.. by old i mean castles, cathedrals from around 800 ad. Yep! It's gots lots of that! Really beautiful Castles and Cathedrals. And German Food too. And Beer Festivals.

title: Being stationed in Wiesbaden, Germany

content: To tell the truth, ya can't go wrong in any part of Germany... in the early '70s, Mystical and me were dirt poor, living on about $140.00 a month, and a big chunk of that going to rent, yet we had a little fast-back Volkswagen; and every weekend we headed for a different little town in the local vicinity just to wander the streets, look at the shops and eat some local food. Every "Berg" has its own little castle somewhere, its own interesting church, and it own beautiful cobble-stoned "Walk-Platz" full of little shops and eateries that are all right off of picture postcards. The people were always very friendly. We always had our little son along, and he usually drew attention, because of his cute, bubbly nature... It was all a wonderful experience!! Wandering and Wondering
reply: To tell the truth, ya can't go wrong in any part of Germany... in the early '70s, Mystical and me were dirt poor, living on about $140.00 a month, and a big chunk of that going to rent, yet we had a little fast-back Volkswagen; and every weekend we headed for a different little town in the local vicinity just to wander the streets, look at the shops and eat some local food. Every "Berg" has its own little castle somewhere, its own interesting church, and it own beautiful cobble-stoned "Walk-Platz" full of little shops and eateries that are all right off of picture postcards. The people were always very friendly. We always had our little son along, and he usually drew attention, because of his cute, bubbly nature... It was all a wonderful experience!! Wandering and Wondering

content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: I know guys who were in the Army and were stationed in Germany. None of them had anything negative to say about Germany! Agreed except that I did run into a few guys that said they hated the "whole damned country". Invariably those who had a negative opinion of Germany never made any effort to learn the language. I learned and loved the place. btw, I was stationed in Worms and traveled a lot of the Mannheim/Heidleberg/Wiesbaden area. Loved stoping bye the Air base mess hall just to eat off plates instead of compartmented steel or plastic trays. Those AF guys always were generous hosts and treated us dogfaces kindly, maybe they were pitying us.
quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: I know guys who were in the Army and were stationed in Germany. None of them had anything negative to say about Germany!
reply: Agreed except that I did run into a few guys that said they hated the "whole damned country". Invariably those who had a negative opinion of Germany never made any effort to learn the language. I learned and loved the place. btw, I was stationed in Worms and traveled a lot of the Mannheim/Heidleberg/Wiesbaden area. Loved stoping bye the Air base mess hall just to eat off plates instead of compartmented steel or plastic trays. Those AF guys always were generous hosts and treated us dogfaces kindly, maybe they were pitying us.
